008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.util.progress;
010
011import imagingbook.common.filter.generic.GenericFilter;
012import imagingbook.common.ij.IjProgressBarMonitor;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * This class represents a "progress monitor". This is a simple {@link Thread}
017 * that queries the attached target task (implementing {@link ProgressReporter})
018 * and calls its {@link #handleProgress(double, long)} method at regular
019 * intervals. {@link ProgressMonitor} implements the {@link AutoCloseable} and
020 * thus can (and should) be used in a try-with-resources context, e.g.,
021 * </p>
022 * 
023 * <pre>
024 * ProgressReporter task = ....; // the activity to be monitored
025 * try (ProgressMonitor m = new ConsoleProgressMonitor(task)) {
026 *     // run task ...
027 * }
028 * </pre>
029 * 
030 * <p>
031 * Otherwise, if not used in a auto-start/close mode, the methods
032 * {@link #start()} and {@link #close()} should be used to "manually" start and
033 * terminate monitoring. See {@link ProgressMonitorExample},
034 * {@link GenericFilter}, {@link ConsoleProgressMonitor} and {@link IjProgressBarMonitor} 
035 * for examples.
036 * </p>
037 * 
038 * <p>
039 * Note that this mechanism cannot be used to monitor activities inside
040 * a constructor, since no reference to the monitored instance is available
041 * before the constructor is finished.
042 * </p>
043 * 
044 * @see ProgressReporter
045 * @see ProgressMonitorExample
046 * @see ConsoleProgressMonitor
047 */
048public abstract class ProgressMonitor extends Thread implements AutoCloseable {
049        
050        /** The default wait time between successive progress queries. */
051        public static final int DefaultWaitTime = 250; // ms
052        
053        private int waitTime = DefaultWaitTime;
054        private final ProgressReporter target;
055
056        private boolean running;
057        private long startTime, endTime;
058        
059        /**
060         * Constructor, starts monitoring immediately.
061         * The target object's {@link ProgressReporter#getProgress()}
062         * method is called it regular intervals.
063         * 
064         * @param target the object (task) to be monitored
065         */
066        public ProgressMonitor(ProgressReporter target) {
067                this(target, true);
068        }
069        
070        /**
071         * Constructor, optionally starts monitoring immediately or waits
072         * for its {@link #start()} method to be called (which starts the 
073         * associated thread).
074         * The target object's {@link ProgressReporter#getProgress()}
075         * method is called it regular intervals.
076         * 
077         * @param target the object (task) to be monitored
078         * @param autoStart starts immediately if true
079         */
080        public ProgressMonitor(ProgressReporter target, boolean autoStart) {
081                if (target == null)
082                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("null target instance!");
083                this.target = target;
084                if (autoStart) {
085                        start();
086                }
087        }
088        
089        /**
090         * The time interval between progress queries can be set with this method.
091         * See also {@link #DefaultWaitTime}.
092         * 
093         * @param waitTime the time interval (in milliseconds)
094         */
095        public void setWaitTime(int waitTime) {
096                this.waitTime = waitTime;
097        }
098        
099        /**
100         * Called periodically by the {@link ProgressMonitor} thread
101         * supplying the current progress value (degree of completion).
102         * It is up to the implementation what action should be performed,
103         * e.g., display the current progress graphically 
104         * (see e.g. {@link IjProgressBarMonitor}).
105         * 
106         * @param progress the current progress value (degree of completion) in [0,1)
107         * @param elapsedNanoTime the time elapsed since this progress monitor was started (in nanoseconds)
108         */
109        public abstract void handleProgress(double progress, long elapsedNanoTime);
110        
111        // --------------------------------------------------------
112
113        @Override
114        public void run() {
115                handleProgress(0, 0);
116                this.startTime = System.nanoTime();
117                running = true;
118                do {
119                        try {
120                                Thread.sleep(waitTime);
121                        } catch (InterruptedException e) {break;}
122                        handleProgress(target.getProgress(), System.nanoTime() - startTime);
123                } while(running);
124                this.endTime = System.nanoTime();
125        }
126        
127        @Override
128        public void close() {
129                running = false;
130        this.interrupt();
131        }
132        
133        // --------------------------------------------------------
134        
135        /**
136         * Returns the time elapsed since monitoring started (in seconds).
137         * @return the elapsed time in seconds
138         */
139        public double getElapsedTime() { // result is in seconds
140                if (running) {
141                        return  (System.nanoTime() - startTime) / 1.0e9d;
142                }
143                else {
144                        return (endTime - startTime) / 1.0e9d;
145                }
146        }
147
148}
